org.fhnw.aigs.client.GUI

Class BaseGameWindow

  • java.lang.Object
    • javafx.scene.Node
      • javafx.scene.Parent
        • javafx.scene.layout.Region
          • javafx.scene.layout.Pane
            • javafx.scene.layout.GridPane
              • org.fhnw.aigs.client.GUI.BaseGameWindow
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    javafx.css.Styleable, javafx.event.EventTarget

    public class BaseGameWindow
extends javafx.scene.layout.GridPane
    This class provides represents the "frame" around a game. It is structured in the following way:
    • On the top, there is the header. It takes up 100% width and 10% height.You can edit it's content via BaseHeader.setGameNameText(java.lang.String) and BaseHeader.setStatusLabelText(java.lang.String), see BaseHeader.
    • In the middle there is the actual content, the game itself. This will take up 85 percent of the space. The content can be accessed via getContent().
    • The footer is the last part which only takes up 5%. It can be accessed via getFooter() but does not have any functionality in the base client.

    v1.0 Initial release
    v1.1 Change of handling and UI improvements
    v1.2 Changes of layer handling
    Version:
    v1.2 (Raphael Stoeckli, 23.04.2014)
    Author:
    Matthias St√∂ckli (v1.0)

    • Field Detail

      • scene

        private javafx.scene.Scene scene
        The JavaFX scene - in some way the application window itself

      • primaryStage

        private javafx.stage.Stage primaryStage
        The stage represents the content of the scene

      • overlay

        private javafx.scene.Node overlay
        Allows to show an overlay like a loading window. Use removeOverlay(), setOverlay(javafx.scene.Node) and fadeOutOverlay() for that purpose.

      • header

        private BaseHeader header
        The header, contains the game title and a status label which can be modified

      • content

        private javafx.scene.Node content
        The actual game content, most of the times an intance of a class inheriting of BaseBoard. Use the setContent(javafx.scene.Node) to set the content.

      • footer

        private javafx.scene.layout.Pane footer
        The footer of the window. It can be changed with setFooter(javafx.scene.layout.Pane) if needed.

      • title

        private java.lang.String title
        The title of the Window

    • Constructor Detail

      • BaseGameWindow

        public BaseGameWindow(javafx.stage.Stage primaryStage,
                      java.lang.String gameStylesheetPath,
                      java.lang.String title)
        This is the recommended constructor. This allows to use a stylesheet which can then be used in other classes such as Fields or Boards.
        Parameters:
        primaryStage - The primary stage which is given by the main method.
        gameStylesheetPath - The (relative) path to a stylesheet (css). Please note that the stylesheet must be stored in a folder which is used as a source folder. Netbeans automatically adds folders to the source folder, in other IDEs it may be necessary to add the folder to the class path. If the stylesheet is store in the "src" folder, it should be recognized by most IDEs immediately.
        title - The title of the game which will be displayed as the window's title.

      • BaseGameWindow

        public BaseGameWindow(javafx.stage.Stage primaryStage,
                      java.lang.String title)
        See BaseGameWindow(javafx.stage.Stage, java.lang.String, java.lang.String). This constructor does not specify a stylesheet.
        Parameters:
        primaryStage - The primary stage which is given by the main method.
        title - The title of the game which will be displayed as the window's title.

    • Method Detail

      • toggleFullScreen

        public void toggleFullScreen()
        Activates full screen mode or deactivates it, if it already is in full scren mode. The process will make use of the Platform.runLater(java.lang.Runnable) method because this opperation must be performed on the JavaFX thread. Please note: As the aspect ratio of normal games will be 1:1, the image may be distortet.

      • removeContent

        public void removeContent()
        See content.

      • InitGame

        public void InitGame(javafx.scene.Node content,
                     ClientGame clientGame)
        Initializes the game.
        This method will call the settings window if no settings are defined or if the window is configured to be visible at every startup.
        Depending on the settings, the setup window or the loading window (overlay) will be enabled. An auomatic connection will be established in case of the loading window. Call this method in the start() method of your game (in Main.java or a similar calss containing the main method)
        Parameters:
        content - The main pane of the game. This could be an instance of BaseBoard or any instance derived from Node like GridPane
        clientGame - The client game object of the game
        Since:
        v1.1

      • setOverlay

        public void setOverlay(javafx.scene.Node overlay)
        See overlay.

      • setOverlay

        public void setOverlay(javafx.scene.Node overlay,
                       boolean overrideRemoveExistingOverlay)
        See overlay.

      • setOverlay

        public void setOverlay(javafx.scene.Node overlay,
                       boolean overrideRemoveExistingOverlay,
                       boolean distinctLayers)
        Parameters:
        distinctLayers - If true, all existing overlays with the same ID as the new one will be removed See overlay.
        Since:
        v1.2

      • removeOverlay

        private void removeOverlay()
        Removes the top layer of the overlay. Use this method if joining or creating a party is failed and the setup window has to be showed again.
        Do not use it to start the party. Use then fadeOutOverlay() instead. See overlay.
        Since:
        v1.1

      • removeOverlay

        private void removeOverlay(java.lang.String id)
        Remove all layers with the specified ID. Uste this Method to avoid double defined layers.
        Do not use it to start the party. Use then fadeOutOverlay() instead. See overlay.
        Parameters:
        id - ID(s) to remove
        Since:
        v1.2

      • fadeOutOverlay

        public void fadeOutOverlay()
        This method allows to fade out an overlay set by setOverlay(javafx.scene.Node).
        Use this method to start the party. If an overlay has to be replaced with another one, use method removeOverlay() instead.
